Award.AwardTitle: PAPM EAGER: Microwell array platform for high-throughput screening and discovery of microbial interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a new tool for the discovery of interactions occurring within root-associated bacterial communities. Thousands of different bacteria persistently live on plant roots where bacterial interactions help shape these communities and are a critical factor in determining plant health. Traditional approaches test only a few interactions at a time, leaving many bacterial communities poorly characterized. By simultaneously testing thousands of different bacterial interactions, our approach will greatly accelerate the pace of discovery. Uncovering these interactions will aid efforts to manipulate bacterial communities to improve food production and environmental decontamination efforts. Our method will be highly adaptable, allowing for examination of any microbial community and for use in any microbiology laboratory. The project involves an interdisciplinary team of engineers and microbiologists that will apply recent advances in microfabrication with concepts from microbial ecology and genetics, thereby providing interdisciplinary training for a post-doctoral researcher and a graduate student. In addition, the project will support an interactive public outreach program at the Flint Hills Discovery Center illustrating the impact of land use management practices on microbiome diversity in the Flint Hills ecoregion, as well as how micro- and nanotechnologies can be used to improve our understanding of microbes.

Microbe-microbe interactions influence microbial community dynamics, composition, and impact on the host. This project aims to develop a high-throughput screening approach for identifying bacterial species that impact a focal bacterial species. The screening platform will use a microwell array to create thousands of unique pairings between the focal species and different bacterial species within a microbiome. Cell pairs will be trapped within their respective wells using a polymer membrane and then monitored with a fluorescent microscope for effects on the focal species. Wells showing enhancement or suppression of focal species function will be extracted and the antagonizing or promoting species will be sequenced for identification. We will validate this technology platform with two screens of Helianthus annuus microbiomes sampled from sites under different land use management regimes at the Konza Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) site. The first screen will identify bacteria that antagonize or promote the growth of the generalist plant pathogen Agrobacterium tumefaciens. To target specific mechanisms of microbial interaction, the second screen will identify microbiome members that either positively or negatively influence induction of A. tumefaciens' quorum sensing system. The established platform will be low-cost, simple to operate, and applicable for discovery in any microbiome.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In natural ecosystems, bacteria exist in complex, heterogenous, and dynamic communities. These communities often contain thousands of different species, and the survival and function of organisms within these communities is influenced by interactions with other microbes present. Understanding these interactions is difficult because there is a lack of experimental tools that are suitable for their characterization. Current microbiology methods for measuring microbe-microbe interactions are slow and laborious, testing only tens of interactions at a time, when many thousands of interactions are possible.

The goal of this project was to develop a novel experimental device that allows for simultaneous observation of bacteria cells as they interact with tens of thousands of different microbes from natural microbial communities. Our approach uses small, micron-sized wells to generate and observe many different combinations of bacterial strains using time lapse fluorescent microscopy. After an interaction of interest is identified in the device, microbes are removed for characterization. The key innovation of our approach is the development and use of a novel membrane that allows for both co-culture of bacteria within the wells and recovery of cells from specific wells. The membrane was designed to degrade under patterned light, releasing bacteria from individual wells after culture so they could be retrieved. Using the developed materials and devices, we were able to successfully screen and discover interactions in plant root microbiomes. We investigated this approach for characterizing interactions that influenced the function of a generalist plant pathogen as well as interactions that influence plant growth promoting bacteria that stimulate root development. We were able to successfully demonstrate that members of a root microbiome that antagonize or promote the growth of these organisms can be identified and isolated. In some cases, we discovered that combinations of several organisms were required to best support bacteria growth. Given these findings, we expect that this device will be useful for developing formulations of bacteria that can be used as biofertilizers for sustainable plant growth or for biocontrol formulations that protect plants from disease. This research has been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at national conferences. An international patent application was also filed on the technology. Additional manuscripts are currently in preparation.  

A broader objective of this project was to disseminate this research to the general public. This occurred through a Science-on-Tap event in Manhattan, KS, where the project was presented to ~100 members of the public through an interactive event. In addition, training opportunities were provided to a post-doc, graduate students in chemical engineering and microbiology, as well three undergraduate students from under-represented groups. Finally, a portion of the research was used to develop class-room based projects in Transport Phenomena courses. These projects followed the process-oriented guided inquiry learning (POGIL) pedagogical method.
